description.narrative: Operations support for the Wildlife Action Group - Malawi for the protection of the Thuma Forest Reserve and Dedza-Salima Forest Reserve elephant population, 2012

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Contributed Funds

description.narrative: Funds will support the operating costs of anti-poaching scouts in two forest reserves that serve as one of the last refuges for elephants near Lake Malawi. Specific activities will include operating costs for the team of twenty scouts and a manager, rations and equipment for patrols, installation of a new radio communications system, basic training, and agricultural extension work and fence maintenance to minimize conflict with local farmers.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Reclaiming the decimated western region of Thuma Forest Reserve, Malawi, for elephant habitat

description.narrative: This project provides support to protect elephants in Thuma and Dedza-Salima forest reserves west of Lake Malawi from poaching pressure and agricultural encroachment. Specific activities will include continued patrolling for the core forested area that provides essential habitat to the elephants, and construction and staffing of a new patrol camp in the remote western part of Thuma Reserve in order to reduce illegal charcoal harvesting and promote restoration of the forest. In addition, funds will be used for a liaison officer and outreach activities to support education programs, wildlife clubs, and sustainable income generating programs for communities outside the reserves.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Canine Detection to Strengthen and Replicate Anti-Trafficking Capacity in Key Countries

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build the anti-wildlife trafficking capacity in to key range, transit and consumer states: Malawi and Kyrgyzstan, by improving, expanding and establishing canine teams for wildlife law enforcement. Multiple species subjected to illicit wildlife trade will benefit from this work, including elephants, bears, pangolins, saiga, and snow leopard. Specific activities include: (1) tracking the activities, costs, processes of establishment and the workflows of canine programs to establish a set of detection dog resources for other wildlife agencies; (2) reviewing the legal foundation for canine-based law enforcement of wildlife laws in key trafficking countries; (3) producing a Best Practices and Feasibility Report on the application of detection dogs to combat wildlife trafficking; (4) Improving the husbandry and training for the Malawi Police Service wildlife detection dogs while expanding their capability to screen at roadblocks, rail and airports and at board crossings; (5) expand detection dog activities in Kyrgyzstan to include wildlife products.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Aerial support for anti-poaching, monitoring and management of Zakouma National Park and Periphery for 2017 and 2018

description.narrative: This ongoing project aims to increase tolerance of elephants in and around Ruaha National Park by assisting local farmers in preventing elephant damage to crops, by conducting outreach and park visitation programs to improve understanding of the importance of the park and by providing opportunities for dialogue between park officials and local residents. Activities will include assisting farmers with constructing beehive fences to deter elephants, conducting education and outreach programs in villages, and operating a park visitation program for local residents to visit Ruaha and meet with park officials.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter wildlife trafficking in Malawi by strengthening the wildlife crime justice sector through improved legislation and regulatory measures; education, training, and capacitybuilding; and improved court outcomes. The project will have a focus on CITES-listed species and address regulatory loopholes, corruption, and weak and inconsistent sentencing for wildlife trafficking crimes. Specific activities will include: (1) developing, passing, and publicizing new regulations in order to realize full enforcement of the new legislation; (2) developing sentencing guidelines for serious wildlife crimes in accordance with new legislation; (3) conducting quarterly case review workshops in Malawi for prosecutors, private litigators, and the judiciary.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: The ICCF Group Conservation Council of Nations (CCN) Project: Engaging the Malawi Parliamentary.Conservation Caucus to Support Policy, Legislative, and Institutional Actions to Combat Wildlife.Crime

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to combat illegal wildlife trafficking (IWT) in Malawi by strengthening governance and the effectiveness of legal/policy frameworks and enforcement bodies through support and engagement of the Malawi Parliamentary Conservation Caucus (MPCC) and the Department of National Parks and Wildlife (DNPW). The project is intended to protect wildlife from poaching, trafficking, corruption, capacity challenges in judicial and prosecutorial authorities, and a lack of an effective regulatory framework to enforce legislation. Activities will include a) MPCC participation as a key stakeholder in the development of wildlife regulations that support enforcement and implementation of Malawis recent Wildlife Amendment Act, b) MPCC facilitation of the implementation of the Malawi Road Map for prosecutors and judges on strategies to effectively handle wildlife crime cases, and c) MPCC facilitation of enhanced anti-corruption frameworks in the wildlife and forestry departments and the Anti-Corruption Bureau.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: CITES AND COMBATTING WILDLIFE CRIME IN MALAWI

description.narrative: A participatory review of existing government capacity to identify opportunities for enhancing efficiency and effectiveness; development of a species identification system for CITES Appendix I and II species; investigative activities of the Wildlife Crime Investigation Unit to pursue wildlife trafficking cases; continuation of on-the-job training for prosecutors and magistrates; capacity-building for a unit that manages all live confiscated CITES-listed species (both plants and animals); and implementation of campaigns that will lead to a reduction in wildlife crime.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date
